title: Thursday, 7th February 2019
bodyHTML:
Shrink Evening
11:12 am
BE11:12am

Can you dominate a pie? That's the hot topic on the AV desk right now.

Blank canvas good morning BE and everyone on the right
BE11:12am

Also: hello. Good morning. Welcome along to Profit Warning Live.

GBKrona Hola - love pies!
VV75 morning
marktime PFC who knew you needed bribes to win oil contracts
SoS Ah now that has always been a difficult question
chopper bear petrofac ocado or equineflu ?
BE11:13am

We've plenty of those today. Some real belters, Advertising, holidays, sausages ....

IMP.GLD Petrofac? Surely a moronic sell off considering no current employees charged by SFO?
11:13 am
BE11:14am

But I guess we can start with serious fraud.

rw42 Can definitely demolish a pie - demolishing it sounds messier and possibly something that might get you thrown out of the restaurant..
Petrofac Ltd (PFC:LSE): Last: 416.73, down 142.27 (-25.45%), High: 517.40, Low: 412.00, Volume: 5.47m
rw42 dominating*
FATDAZ morning
BE11:14am

David Lufkin pleads guilty.

11:14 am
BE11:15am

https://www.ft.com...-88a4-c32129756dd8

Otter Hello internet friends.
BE11:15am

The UK’s Serious Fraud Office has said a former executive at the oil company Petrofac has pleaded guilty to bribery in relation to corrupt payments the group made to win contracts in Iraq and Saudi Arabia worth hundreds of millions of dollars.

David Lufkin, a British national and Petrofac’s former global head of sales, was involved in payments made by Petrofac to agents to secure the work on projects including a $330m contract on Iraq’s Badra oilfield. The company was awarded the contract in February 2012.

The SFO, which prosecuted Mr Lufkin, said Petrofac also offered bribes to influence variations to the Badra deal and to extend a related contract, but did not obtain the work and no payments were ultimately made in those cases.

BE11:15am

Sentencing to happen later.

WP77 PPB(-1.53%), PTEC(-1.86%),GVC(-1.68%),WMH(-1%) do these pampered ponys really get sick?
11:15 am
BE11:16am

Now .......

BE11:16am

..... we have two arguments here.

CryptoWhipto Peel bearish on Wealth and Asset managers, any insight?
BE11:17am

First, we have the argument that the fall in Petrofac far exceeds any potential fine the SFO's likely to levy.

Waterloo EU forecast growth down. Synchronised slowdowns. They should name a dance after it.
FJ SFO has been investigating at least since 02/2018???
11:17 am
BE11:17am

Particularly if you spin all the way back to when HuffPost broke the allegations in 2016-ish, when Petrofac was trading at about 900p.

BE11:18am

That's the Morgan Stanley argument.

Waterloo Oh and they start the hearings today into Mr T's tax returns. He did say some months back that if they did it would be 'war'. See he's just tweeted about it
BE11:18am

We calculate that Petrofac's 35% underperformance relative to the sector since the initial May 2017 SFO announcement represents $1.282bn of lost market value, and the 60% underperformance since March 2016 when allegations first appeared equates to $2,586bn of lost value. We continue to believe this will ultimately prove a more than sufficient discount to reflect the outcome of the SFO situation. We have previously highlighted that the largest SFO fine, for Rolls Royce, was $497m in 2017 (3% of market cap at the time), which represented 258m for repaying profits on deals covered and £239m penalty.

Blank canvas Has Martin Sorrell done something which has pulled the rug from under WPP?
WP77 PPB, GVC, WMH do these pampered ponys really get sick?
11:19 am
BE11:19am

We should note the Petrofac statement also, emphasising that .....

BE11:19am

1.) No charges have been brought against the company, officers or employees. 2.) No current board member of Petrofac is alleged to have been involved. 3.) The SFO charges relate to a former employee of a subsidiary, 4.) Petrofac has compliance procedures in place.

VV75 @Blank canvas, Publicis had figures out this morning
Tom Dalgleish With RR did the customer receive its money back ?
Shinshin Presumably if the penalty for a qualified lawyer and MP perverting the course of justice is 3 months inside, then Mr Lufkin should be back at home by Easter ?
BE11:20am

However, against that, we have to note that the problem for Petrofac keeps growing. Spinning back to the 2016 initial report it was possible bribes in Central Asia prior to 2010.

Blank canvas VV75: thanks - will dig in that direction
11:21 am
BE11:21am

Whereas today's rap-sheet looks like .....

BE11:21am

1.) $2.2m payment to 2 agents to secure $330m Badra Iraq contract in 2012, 2.) $4m to an agent to secure the $400m Fao Iraq contract in 2012, 3.) $5.9m payment for the $463m Petro Rabigh contract 2012 in Saudi, 4.) $21.4m payment for Jazan refinery in 2012 worth $1.7bn, 5.) $19.5m payments for Fadhili in Saudi worth $1.56bn in 2015.

BE11:21am

... all of which are post the 2010 UK Bribery Act.

11:22 am
BE11:22am

So maybe we have to start talking about reputational damage, which is an unquantifiable.

BE11:24am

What's clear is that it's pretty difficult to get a value on Petrofac near to the current price if you see the potential fine in isolation.

BE11:24am

As per this recent thing from HSBC:

11:24 am
BE11:24am

Pharma Is that a reputation for bribery, or a reputation for being caught paying bribes?
hornblower anyone got an idea how come Barclays turns up from nowhere on Greencore register with 9% holding?
Roidster bonjour all @BE ;)
BE11:26am

And net debt of ~$200m or so doesn't look overly troubling.

BE11:26am

Anyway, that's Petrofac.

11:26 am
undefined
BE11:26am

Publicis warning noted on the right.

BE11:26am

Which has done this .....

Roidster What about cranswick @BE or am i already late LOL?
11:26 am
WPP PLC (WPP:LSE): Last: 805.60, down 68 (-7.78%), High: 848.00, Low: 804.20, Volume: 3.33m
BE11:27am

.... So Q4 organic sales growth was meant to be 2.5%.

BE11:27am

..... Instead, it was -0.3%.

Curious I heard from people working for WPP owned companies they're really tightening their belts
11:27 am

Management reference FMCG spending in North America turning nasty, along with client losses including in China.

BE11:28am

All of which plays into the theme that advertising agencies are snookered.

wayneJ Isn't WPP about to sell Kantar? Some interesting prices being speculated?
BE11:29am

As budgets go in house, or on point-of-sale stuff, or towards Instagram influencers and crap like that.

wayneJ Regarding advertising being snookered - isn't there an issue regarding exactly how effective web advertising really is? (Anything that doesn't create sales is called marketing / brand awareness etc)
marktime What does LK Hyman think?
11:30 am
BE11:30am

There was a good Redburn note on it all last month, summarised here: https://www.ft.com...-b329-c7e6ceb5ffdf

Trumpaloompa Any grey on Accesso, BE?
jaws BE what M Stanley says on Barratt BDEV today please or anything in wire card? Thanks.
BE11:30am

Here's Cazenove.

BE11:30am

Publicis published a weak set of results last night with Q4 organic
revenues declining by -0.3% (versus ZF consensus at +2.5%).
Excluding PHS (held for sale) Q4 organic revenue growth was +0.5%. The
weakness was in particular driven by N America (also Asia) and
management stated that “we suffered from the usual year-end volatility
and the higher-than-expected attrition in traditional advertising, mainly
from several FMCG clients in the US”. A solid execution on costs (60bps
margin increase y/y) and a new €400m share buyback program (due to
lack of M&A options) are small positives but will likely be overshadowed
by the weak top line momentum. Core advertisers are spending less which
increasingly is becoming a structural (rather than cyclical) issue for the
industry. We materially cut our mid-term organic revenue growth
estimates (from c.2% to now +0.9%/+0.1% in 19E/20E) and question
company guidance for +4% org. growth in 2020E. Given low risk-reward
and limited data points to push back on structural concerns, we downgrade PUB from OW to N.

11:31 am
BE11:31am

Our 19E/20E PBT estimates fall by -11%/-21% driven by the
reduction in organic revenue growth and lower margins. While these
estimates may prove to be conservative, we see limited catalysts for a rerating.
The debate around structural bear arguments such as 1) lower ad
spend by advertisers long term, 2) disintermediation by global tech
players and 3) market share losses to consultancies is likely to continue
with limited datapoints to get more excited short term and we see limited
scope for the shares to re-rate short term

Tom Dalgleish So like-for-like, BE?
Pharma @wayneJ - was thinking the same thing. I think advertising agencies might make a comeback when everyone realises the emperor of web adverts is wearing no clothes.
undefined
wayneJ Or on a eyeball to eyeball basis I am increasingly thinking that a 30 sec slot on TV during a high engagement programme is actually worth more than a ad on a instagram or facebook feed being watched by a bot or accidentally clicked whilst bouncing up and down on a train.
BE11:33am

I'll address your many questions on the right as best I can, or possibly ignore them.

Blackbag99 Is disintermediation still likely to happen. When you look at Googles numbers, they have appeared to have lost money.
11:33 am
BE11:33am

Starting with Ocado.

Ocado Group PLC (OCDO:LSE): Last: 876.40, down 92 (-9.50%), High: 960.60, Low: 876.20, Volume: 1.98m
wayneJ The other issue is that WPP was trading at about 1/2 the valuation of Publicis or Omnicom.
casapinos How does advertising spend relate to wealth of relevant eyeballs??
BE11:34am

That's down 15% or so in two days which, if you assume Tuesday's price was correct, has completely written off the value of the retail arm.

marktime Webvan "folded" into Amazon ...
11:34 am
BE11:34am

A point made by Bernstein this morning:

BE11:34am

The Retail group made £82.5m of EBITDA in 2018. Using a 10X EBITDA multiple, that gets you to an £825m valuation out of a total market cap of around £6.2 bn

wayneJ Doesn't the loss of CEO improve the bottom line of WPP by about £100M which on a multiple of 8x gives £800M; given the current mkt cap of £10bn that is a not uninteresting 8% improvement in value?! :-)
BE11:36am

Bruno's back-of-envelope calculations suggest a 10% reduction in total capacity of 30,000 orders per week, but with 5,000 orders able to go to the other warehouses and another 3,000 as Erith expansion gets rushed, so net 7.5% reduction .....

11:36 am
BE11:37am

The combination of a 7.5% reduction on 13% of the EV, should lead to a 1% EV and share price reduction (Enterprise value and market cap are very similar in the case of Ocado).

wayneJ Actually WPP now looks like it is on a PE of about 7.5x
BE11:37am

So ..... it's pretty clear we're no longer talking about lost orders. We're talking about the question of whether the warehouses can operate without bursting into flames occasionally.

chopper bear pfc under £4 live - seems overdone surely
BE11:38am

As we said yesterday, Andover's the show home of Ocado's tech franchise.

11:38 am
BE11:38am

Here's Barclays:

BE11:38am

This may of course simply be a very unfortunate and isolated incident, but existing and potential partners could be forgiven for taking a close interest. Ocado can at least try to divert its demand into its other CFCs, but for those partners who have ordered just one (Casino, ICA, Sobeys) there would be a major problem if their sole CFC was disrupted due to fire (or indeed other reasons). It is not inconceivable that the CFC design has to be improved from a fire protection perspective, which could delay the construction of ordered CFCs and delay the addition of new partners. ^

BE11:39am

To which Bernstein says, "nah".

11:39 am
BE11:40am

Reports suggesting the fire "started in a corner of the ambient grid" and "involved automated packaging machinery", suggesting it's not the really high tech kit that combusted.

BE11:40am

Packaging machinery is old-world technology. Whilst it shouldn’t go up in flames, it does seem plausible that hot plastic, as part of the packaging, could catch fire. That would not be a risk at the robotic centers that Ocado sells and surely would be easily fixable.

BE11:41am

Bruno argued that the picker grid would've shut down at the first sign of a spark, because it's complicated and highly sensitive. What we have here is a simple factory machinery fire.

11:41 am
BE11:41am

[I}f there were a structural problem in the design, it would have been causing distortion problems well before this fire started. The fact that the CFCs were able to scale up so quickly and run for so long without such distortions, suggest to us that this is not a structural problem in the CFC design.

BE11:42am

And .....

casapinos robot gives off sparks.......?
BE11:42am

[T]he 14% seems like a massive overreaction to this fire. Whilst the retail business will be materially impacted, we see no reason yet to consider this a major setback for the Ocado technology business. This provides a new entry point for investors.

Tom Dalgleish It's a fire suppression problem amongst the stacks of plastic tubs
wayneJ Just for clarification purposes - I assume 'activist short' does not cover setting fire to target companies' facilities? And I assume robots are not allowed to be activists?
FJ The insurance companies will therefore not raise premiums?
11:42 am
BE11:43am

Should also note that Peel Hunt's back making lemonade from lemons.

Pharma Fire suppression should get easier when you remove the people.
BE11:43am

Still hold post yesterday's downgrade, but itching to go positive again by the sound of things.

BE11:43am

Ocado has been one of the most successful UK technology
companies over the past decade, culminating in an equity
performance over the past year that it deserves. The innovative,
forward thinking, technology-first mind-set of the management
and employee base has risen to the occasion. Whilst the events of
the past few days have caused short-term disruption, they have
given Ocado an opportunity to raise the bar even further, as
shown by decisions made following events at ASOS and
Northgate Information Systems in the past. With a supportive
shareholder base, Ocado must now take the findings of the
investigation into those events and supercharge its operation. We
take great solace in that it can do that now. Today, only 10% of
its orders on Ocado.com are processed via Andover (with
Ocado.com as a whole, arguably only 20% of today’s equity
value) and that the CFCs for its Solutions partners have yet to be
completed (arguably 80%+ of today’s equity value). This will
allow it to future proof itself further. Ensuring it is protected into
the longer term, when eventually 100% of orders on Ocado.com
go through its automated, operationally efficient warehouses, and
its successful Solutions deals with the likes of Kroger and Sobeys
go live.

11:43 am
undefined
BE11:45am

Should loop back to Tui, I guess.

Tui AG (TUI:LSE): Last: 982.20, down 201.8 (-17.04%), High: 1,067, Low: 963.00, Volume: 4.22m

Profit warning.

BE11:45am

BE11:46am

11:46 am

Top marks, incidentally, to HSBC, who downgraded Tui yesterday: https://www.ft.com...-88a4-c32129756dd8

BE11:47am

Anyway, guidance was for 10% ebita growth and is now for zero so we're looking at the consensus EPS falling 13%-ish.

Here's Kepler.

marktime @BE as opposed to bottom marks to Morgan Stanley for uprating PFC
11:48 am
BE11:48am

We assume that the bankruptcy case of Germania was the final step for the profit warning, even though it was not separately called out. The profit warning obviously leaves many questions with respect to a potentially changed dividend policy and a potentially changed capex plan, which will obviously affect TUI’s free cash flow, as well as its new leverage ratio guidance. Pending the conference call, we have changed our rating from Buy to Under Review. Our target price was based on an equally weighted sum-of-the-parts and DCF method. If we were to just adjust the group EBITA to flat YOY via lower estimates in for the markets & airlines division, our SOP-derived target price would drop from EUR15.20 to EUR14.40, hence by 5%.

wayneJ What is the incidence of fire at UK internet retailers (eg Ocado, Asos) versus their equivalents such as Amazon? I don't seem to have heard of fire issues in Bezo's playhouse.
BE11:49am

And UBS.

Pharma @FATDAZ - it's been done. One of the Bond films used it as a plot device I think.
BE11:49am

We calculate the new guidance implies a 24% cut to Markets and Airlines
FY19 EBITA expectations (at FY18 TUI was expecting Markets and Airlines EBITA to grow ~10%). The FY19 decline in Markets & Airlines profitability should be offset by growth in Hotels and Cruises. A good part of this growth is heavy capex driven (e.g. opening of ~16 hotels (UBSe) and 3 new cruise ships). Capex expenditure is expected to normalise starting FY20, providing therefore less support to EBITA growth. As we see Hotel Revpar at a peak – it is not obvious to us which will be the main drivers of EBITA growth in FY20 and thereafter.

wayneJ @Fatdaz - that is a good script idea.
11:50 am
BE11:50am

We calculate the updated guidance implies a ~€80m decline in Markets and Airlines EBITA y/y. Considering that in FY19 TUI was set to benefit from the non-repeat of the 2018 one off costs (Niki bankruptcy €20m, ATC disruptions €13m) this implies the actual decline is Markets & Airline profits is expected to be ~€113m (vs. FY18 EBITA of €453m). It is not clear to us if the initiatives management is taking to offset the situation will lead to higher adjustments in FY19 (vs. €125m prior guidance). Our view is that the ~600 UK high-street retail shops represent a cost disadvantage vs. new digital competitors

BE11:50am

In contrast to FY18, TUI has not offered an outlook of the net debt development for FY19 although it has flagged heavy capex and potential aircraft financing of €300- 400m. It is not clear if the weaker market environment in Markets and Airlines will also have a negative impact on working capital (prior expectations inflow of ~€100-125m in FY19). On a separate note, with ~ €1.2bn goodwill related to the Northern Region – and downward pressure on profitability, we believe the risk to goodwill impairment has increased.

FATDAZ @pharma yes but not very well and not from the standpoint of the perpetrator
FATDAZ @waynej thanks glad you think so
undefined
FATDAZ coming back to the travel industry did I see that Thomas Cook wants to sell off its airline to raise cash

BE11:53am

BE11:54am

Not sure it's box office gold, TBH.

Thomas Cook Group plc (TCG:LSE): Last: 34.90, up 3.82 (+12.29%), High: 37.16, Low: 29.24, Volume: 19.61m

11:55 am

BE11:55am

Citi can summarise .....

BE11:56am

Thomas Cook announces a strategic review of the Group Airline,
maintains FY19 expectations and points to consumer uncertainty in Summer-19 bookings. Q1 Group Revenue was +1% YoY at £1,656m, (2% below our expectation), EBIT margin declined -50bps to -3.5% and underlying EBIT loss was €14m lower YoY at €60m (Citi €53m). Net Debt is +22% YoY at £1,588m (Citi €1,646m) and debt covenant tests were met (covenants are unspecified). Management say "healthy" liquidity headroom was maintained over the low cash period, with a buffer of £150m-£200m.

Tom Dalgleish @FJ, depends on whether said cheap hotel recycles salami from the previous day
11:56 am
BE11:56am

Note that Thomas Cook's doing okay relatively speaking because it's slashing inventory and Tui's not because it's doing the opposite.

Blackbag99 I am surprised TUI didn't mention Brexit. I would have thought uncertainty could have been easy to blame
BE11:57am

One can hold pricing, the other can't.

BE11:57am

A potential sale of the Airline raises possibilities for market consolidation (also alluded to in TUI's statement this morning), whereby a European competitor could bid for the Airline, leaving the remaining Thomas Cook Tour Operator business potentially attractive to non-EU bidders, in our view, looking to grow their footprint in this market.

11:57 am

What are we missing? There's sausages.

Cranswick PLC (CWK:LSE): Last: 2,508, down 456 (-15.38%), High: 2,602, Low: 2,340, Volume: 1.03m

Q3 LFL sales down 2% against +1.1% in the first half.

VV75 @Swedes, scroll up

chopper bear scroll up

BE12:00pm

There's a bit of a price war for pork, though you may not have noticed. Here's Peel Hunt.

FJ year of the recycled salami
12:00 pm
BE12:00pm

We already knew that volume growth was slowing and that the lack of material new business wins would result in a duller LFL performance. However, we were not expecting volumes to actually decline in Q3. This reduction is wide-spread, with only poultry and continental products in growth in the period.
The reduction in input prices (pig prices are down 7% vs last year) and rising pig prices in China will mitigate the impact, but the lower volumes and higher labour costs (minimum wage +4.4%) result in the c4% reduction to 2019 profits. This will result in profits growing by c2% excluding last year’s 53rd week.
The company has guided to lower margins next year, which is not surprising given the weak volumes and ongoing labour cost inflation. In addition, the
market has become more challenging. Tulip (owned by Danish Crown) has been struggling for some time and we understand losses have been widening. The company is undertaking a restructuring programme, with 300-400 job losses recently announced. Unfortunately for Cranswick, an unstable competitor is not conducive to stable pricing.

Viking1 Comment on BOE cut on growth , sterling tanking
BE12:01pm

Do Cranswick host investor tours of the facilities?

BornCynic Thanks BE / ROTR

FATDAZ @waterloo have been asking that question for about 6 or 7 months but not seen an answer as yet
BE12:04pm

The world economy has continued to slow over recent months, with a broad-based softening across all regions. That deceleration reflects the past tightening in global financial conditions, as well as the initial impact of trade tensions on business sentiment. Global growth is expected to dip below trend in coming quarters, weighing on UK net trade, before rising to around potential rates. Activity is projected to be supported by the more accommodative monetary policies in all major economic areas that markets now expect.

12:04 pm
BE12:04pm

UK economic growth slowed in late 2018 and appears to have weakened further in early 2019. This slowdown mainly reflects softer activity abroad and the greater effects from Brexit uncertainties at home. These uncertainties could lead to greater-than-usual short-term volatility in UK data, which may therefore provide less of a signal about the medium-term outlook. Heightened uncertainty and elevated bank funding costs are assumed to subside over time, as greater clarity on future trading arrangements is assumed to emerge. These developments, together with looser fiscal policy, provide support to domestic spending. In the Committee’s central projection, quarterly GDP growth recovers later this year, with four-quarter growth rising to 2% by the end of the forecast period.

Blank canvas thanks for everything today BE and ROTR
Ghazali @wayneJ imagine being a muslim and trying to avoid the different names of pig....none of which you know.
